questions.text: Which of the following Clark levels indicates that malignant melanoma has invaded the subcutaneous tissue?
questions.explanation:
Clark Level

Skin Layer Involved

Level I

Epidermis

Level II

(Option A ruled out)

Papillary Dermis

Level III

(Option B ruled out)

Junction of Papillary and Reticular Dermis

Level IV

(Option C ruled out)

Reticular Dermis

Level V

(Option D)

Subcutaneous Tissue

Stage

Depth of Invasion

Description

Stage I

< 0.75 mm

Very thin melanoma, confined to the superficial layers of the skin.

Stage II

0.75 - 1.5 mm

Thin to intermediate melanoma, with slight invasion into the dermis.

Stage III

1.6 - 4.0 mm

Intermediate to thick melanoma, with significant invasion into the deeper dermis.

Stage IV

> 4.0 mm

Very thick melanoma, with deep invasion possibly extending into subcutaneous tissue.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding basal cell carcinoma?

options.label: A
options.text: Superficial BCC typically appears with a thin pearly border

options.label: B
options.text: Nodular is the least common type of BCC

options.label: C
options.text: Morpheaform variant is the most common type of BCC

options.label: D
options.text: The prognosis is very poor for all cases

questions.correct_answer: A. Superficial BCC typically appears with a thin pearly border

questions.text: All of these are used for flap monitoring except:
questions.explanation:
CLINICAL FEATURE

ARTERIAL INSUFFICIENCY

VENOUS INSUFFICIENCY

Temperature

Cold

Warm

Color

Pale/White

Congested, Dusky/blue/purple

Capillary refill

Delayed

Quick

Pin-prick

Reduced blood flow

Increased blood flow

questions.text: Which of the following types do osteomyocutaneous flaps belong to?
Which of the following is an example of a free flap?

A 45-year-old man presents with a large soft tissue defect on his lower leg following a motorcycle accident. The wound measures 10 cm x 15 cm and involves exposure of the tibia. The plastic surgeon is considering an axial flap for reconstruction. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the usage of an axial flap?

options.label: A
options.text: Axial pattern flaps derive their blood supply directly from a fasciocutaneous artery that runs beneath the flap's longitudinal axis.

options.label: B
options.text: It allows for a larger flap design compared to random pattern flaps and delivers better cosmetic results

options.label: C
options.text: Deltopectoral flap is a type of axial flap

options.label: D
options.text: Due to larger size, axial flaps require a high complexity, multi-step method for reconstruction of defects

questions.correct_answer: D. Due to larger size, axial flaps require a high complexity, multi-step method for reconstruction of defects

questions.text: Regarding the use of random flaps in grafting, which of the following statements is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: V-Y Plasty is a random flap used for fingertips and extremities

options.label: B
options.text: Random flaps rely on perfusion from the subdermal vascular plexus which is a low-pressure system

options.label: C
options.text: Z-Plasty is used for lengthening of tissue and scars.

options.label: D
options.text: Due to the tenuous blood supply, a minimum length-width ratio of 3:1 is required

questions.correct_answer: D. Due to the tenuous blood supply, a minimum length-width ratio of 3:1 is required
questions.explanation:
V-Y Plasty Z-Plasty
Used for fingertips and extremities. (Option A ruled out) Used for lengthening of tissue and scars (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents with a progressively enlarging, painless mass in his groin. A biopsy confirms a diagnosis of soft tissue sarcoma. Which of the following characteristics would most likely increase the probability of lymph node involvement in this patient?

A 35-year-old woman with a family history of multiple cancers presents with a soft tissue mass. Genetic testing reveals a TP53 mutation. Which of the following is the most likely clinical course associated with her condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Increased risk of developing gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST)

options.label: C
options.text: High likelihood of developing soft tissue sarcomas, breast cancer, and brain tumors

options.label: D
options.text: Predominantly risk of osteosarcoma and leukemia

questions.correct_answer: C. High likelihood of developing soft tissue sarcomas, breast cancer, and brain tumors
questions.explanation:
Syndrome

Mutated Gene(s)

Clinical Features

Li-Fraumeni Syndrome

TP53

High risk of soft tissue sarcomas, breast cancer, brain tumors, osteosarcoma, adrenocortical carcinoma, and other early-onset cancers.

Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1)

NF1

Development of multiple neurofibromas, café-au-lait spots, and malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors.

Gardner's Syndrome

APC

Associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), desmoid tumors (a type of aggressive fibromatosis), and colorectal cancer.

Hereditary Retinoblastoma

RB1

Increased risk of retinoblastoma, osteosarcoma, and other soft tissue sarcomas; typically present in childhood.

Werner Syndrome

WRN

Premature aging, increased risk of various cancers including soft tissue sarcomas, especially in older adults.

Gorlin Syndrome (NBCCS)

PTCH1

Increased risk of basal cell carcinomas, jaw cysts, medulloblastomas, and rare occurrences of soft tissue sarcomas like rhabdomyosarcoma.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the OPD by his mother with complaints of swelling on her nape. On examination, a hard, freely mobile, and slow-growing mass is seen. A photograph of the lesion is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate clinical diagnosis for this patient?
All of the following conditions resolve spontaneously in an infant except

A 28-year-old female patient came to OPD complaining of swelling on the side of her face. On examination, the swelling was painless, smooth, soft, and non-tender. A CT scan was done to rule out dural attachment and a diagnosis of angular dermoid was made. How will you manage the case?

options.label: C
options.text: Wide local excision with a 2 cm margin

questions.text: A 64-year-old male patient came to the OPD with complaints of swelling on the back of the neck. O/E the swelling is soft and doughy to the touch and non-tender. A diagnosis of lipoma is made. What is the definitive management of this condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Wide local excision with sentinel node biopsy

options.label: C
options.text: Excision of the cyst with the wall

options.label: D
options.text: Incision and drainage followed by excision

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of a painful swelling present on the trunk. On examination, tenderness and pus discharge present with a black-colored punctum seen. A provisional diagnosis of an infected sebaceous cyst is made. Identify the incorrect statement about this condition.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a type of retention cyst

options.label: C
options.text: Black colored punctum is present on the cyst

options.label: D
options.text: There is the proliferation of epidermal cells

questions.text: The following are good prognostic factors for melanoma except

options.label: A
options.text: No or very few mitoses (<1 per mm sq)

questions.text: A patient with a skin graft is experiencing mild swelling and oozing at the graft site 24 hours after surgery. Which phase of graft take is most likely occurring?
Which of the following statements is true about malignant melanoma?

options.label: A
options.text: CK-20 is a positive marker for malignant melanoma

options.label: B
options.text: Lentigo Maligna is the most malignant type of malignant melanoma

options.label: C
options.text: Lymphatic spread is the common route of metastasis

options.label: D
options.text: Most common site of metastasis is the Lymph Node

questions.correct_answer: C. Lymphatic spread is the common route of metastasis

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents with a large, aggressive squamous cell carcinoma on his lower lip. After initial treatment attempts, the tumor remains persistent. Which of the following treatment options is most appropriate to ensure complete removal of the tumor while minimizing damage to surrounding healthy tissue?

A 65-year-old farmer presents with a persistent, scaly lesion on his ear. The lesion has irregular, everted edges and has been gradually growing as shown below. Which of the following is the most common causative factor for his condition?

A 62-year-old male presents with a slow-growing, pearly nodule on his nose. The lesion shows telangiectatic vessels on its surface and has a central depression. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic method to confirm the diagnosis of this skin lesion?

A 65-year-old man presents with a non-healing ulcer on the popliteal surface of his leg that has been present for several months. The ulcer developed at the site of a burn scar he sustained 30 years ago. On examination, the ulcer is painless, slow-growing, and has irregular borders as shown in the image? What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Wide local excision followed by flap cover

options.label: C
options.text: Wide local excision followed by flap cover and radiotherapy

questions.correct_answer: B. Wide local excision followed by flap cover
questions.explanation:
Marjolin’s Ulcer

Definition
  • Low-grade Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC)

Common Sites of Development
  • Post-burn scar
  • Long-standing venous ulcer
  • Chronic ulcer due to trauma
  • Chronic discharging osteomyelitis sinus
  • Post-radiation ulcer

Pathophysiology
  • Develops in scar tissue due to chronic irritation

Characteristic Features
  • Painless (no nerves in scar tissues)
  • Slow growing
  • No regional LN metastasis (no lymphatics in scar tissue)

Investigation of Choice
  • Biopsy

Management
  • Wide local excision followed by flap cover
  • Radiotherapy should be avoided (as it is radio-resistant and also to prevent obliterative end arteritis) (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: Match the following types of ulcers with their characteristic edge appearance: Conditions Edges 1. Healing Ulcer a. Punched-out edges 2. Ischaemic Ulcer b. Undermined edges 3. Tubercular Ulcer c. Sloping edges 4. Basal Cell Carcinoma d. Everted edges 5. Squamous Cell Carcinoma e. Rolled or Pearly white edges
questions.explanation:
Type of edges

Clinical conditions

Details

Sloping edge
  • Healing ulcer
  • Varicose ulcer
  • Inner part: Red (healthy granulation tissue)
  • Middle part: Blue (epithelial proliferation)
  • Outer part: White (scar/fibrous tissue)

Undermined edge
  • Tubercular ulcers
  • Disease process advances in the deeper plane (subcutaneous tissue) whereas (skin) epidermis proliferates inwards

Punched out edge
  • Arterial / Ischemic ulcers
  • Gummatous (syphilitic) ulcer
  • Trophic ulcer
  • Due to endarteritis

Raised and beaded edge

Rolled out / Pearly white edge
  • Rodent ulcer- Basal cell carcinoma
  • Beads are due to proliferating active cells
  • Pearly white in appearance

Everted edge / Rolled out edge
  • Squamous cell carcinoma
  • Due to the spill of proliferating malignant tissue over the normal skin

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of diabetes presents with a chronic wound on his lower leg. On examination, you observe a well-defined lesion with the following characteristics: The deepest part of the lesion shows exposed muscle tissue. The exposed surface appears red and moist with some granulation tissue. There is a distinct boundary between healthy skin and the wound. A narrow area surrounds the wound where the skin appears different from both the healthy skin and the wound itself. Based on this clinical scenario, which of the following correctly matches the described features with the parts of an ulcer?

options.label: A
options.text: Exposed muscle - Floor; Red, moist surface with granulation - Base; Boundary of healthy skin - Edge; Narrow surrounding area - Margin

options.label: B
options.text: Exposed muscle - Base; Red, moist surface with granulation - Floor; Boundary of healthy skin - Margin; Narrow surrounding area - Edge

options.label: C
options.text: Exposed muscle - Floor; Red, moist surface with granulation - Base; Boundary of healthy skin - Margin; Narrow surrounding area - Edge

options.label: D
options.text: Exposed muscle - Base; Red, moist surface with granulation - Edge; Boundary of healthy skin - Floor; Narrow surrounding area - Margin

questions.correct_answer: B. Exposed muscle - Base; Red, moist surface with granulation - Floor; Boundary of healthy skin - Margin; Narrow surrounding area - Edge

questions.text: Which of the following is not a type of fasciocutaneous flap?
questions.explanation:
Anatomical types based on type of tissue

Cutaneous flap
  • Forehead flap, Deltopectoral flap

Fasciocutaneous flap
  • Radial forearm flap, Scapular flap, Lateral arm flap, Groin flap (Option A, B & D ruled out)

Muscle flap
  • Gluteus maximus muscle flap, Gracilis flap, Tensor fascia lata muscle flap

Myocutaneous flap
  • Pectoralis major myocutaneous flap, Latissimus dorsi flap—composite flap

Osteomyocutaneous flaps
  • Radius with brachioradialis and skin—composite flap,
  • Rib with intercostal muscles and skin—composite flap

Anatomical types based on the source of vascular supply

Random Pattern Flap
  • Rely on low pressure found in subdermal plexus
  • Used to reconstruct small but full-thickness defect
  • Not amenable to skin grafting

Axial Flap
  • Based on the named vessel
  • If the axial flap remains attached to its proximal blood supply & transferred to a defect known as pedicle flap

Free Flap
  • Autogenous transplant of vascularized tissues
  • There is devascularization from donor site & revascularization at recipient bed

questions.text: Which of the following is not an absolute indication for flap surgery?

options.label: B
options.text: Exposed bony prominences in the joint area

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with extensive third-degree burns requires skin grafting. The surgical team opts for a meshed split-thickness skin graft (STSG). Which of the following is a key benefit of using a meshed skin graft in this scenario?

options.label: B
options.text: Coverage of a large area with minimal donor skin

questions.correct_answer: B. Coverage of a large area with minimal donor skin

questions.text: A 45-year-old male undergoes a split-thickness skin graft for a large wound on his leg. Three days postoperatively, the graft appears swollen with fluid accumulating underneath it. Which of the following complications is most likely?
A patient needs a graft to cover a small, non-weight-bearing area that is prone to contraction. Which type of graft would be most appropriate to minimize the risk of contraction?

options.label: A
options.text: Thiersch graft, due to its minimal contraction

options.label: B
options.text: Wolfe graft, due to its full-thickness nature

options.label: C
options.text: Split-thickness graft, because it can cover larger areas

options.label: D
options.text: Composite graft, because it includes skin and underlying tissue

questions.correct_answer: B. Wolfe graft, due to its full-thickness nature
questions.explanation:
Feature

Thiersch Graft

(Split-Thickness Skin Graft)

Wolfe Graft

(Full-Thickness Skin Graft)

Type of Skin Grafting

Split-thickness

Full-thickness

Composition

Epidermis + part of dermis

Epidermis + full thickness of dermis

Graft Size

Large grafts can be taken

Only small grafts can be taken

Graft Survival

Easier

More difficult

Donor Site Healing

Heals spontaneously, allowing repeated grafts

Permanent defect develops, preventing repeated grafts

Graft Contraction

Significant contraction, leading to poor cosmetic appearance

Lesser contraction, better cosmetic appearance

Common Donor Sites

Inner thigh, upper arm, flexor aspect of forearm, abdominal wall

Upper eyelid, retro auricular skin, supraclavicular skin, antecubital skin, inframammary skin, inguinal skin, genital skin, gluteal skin

Donor Site Exclusions

None

Axilla is not used as a donor site

Advantages of Harvesting

Allows calibration of thickness and large area coverage

Calibration of thickness for small but thick grafts

questions.text: During a skin grafting procedure, the surgeon opts for a tool that can precisely control the thickness of the graft to ensure uniformity. Which of the following instruments is most appropriate for this task?
